awd_titl_txt: Development of algorithms combining molecular dynamics with time-dependent quantum statistical mechanics for environment-assisted electronic transport through biomolecules
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, co-funded by the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry and the Condensed Matter and Materials Theory program in the Division of Materials Research, Professor Branislav Nikolic of the University of Delaware is developing a new theoretical model with supporting computer programs open to the public. This model will allow researchers to simulate the transport of small charged or neutral molecules through larger molecules of biological interest. These biomolecules can be coupled to small, microscopic devices. The development of the theoretical models to simulate the combination of biological molecules to these devices is critical to develop fast and low-cost DNA and protein sequencing. Such research could be extended to the development of personalized medicine, as well as for the development of systems that generate fuels directly from sunlight. This research at the intersection of chemistry, physics, biology and engineering trains students and postdoctoral fellows to pursue careers in basic research, industrial applications and high performance scientific computing. 

This research develops multiscale theoretical and computational tools for systems containing very large number of atoms by combining classical molecular dynamics, nonequilibrium Green functions + density functional theory for multiterminal molecular electronics, and time-dependent quantum transport algorithms of reduced computational complexity (scaling linearly in the number of time steps). The tools are employed to model and design nanostructures made of two-dimensional materials (like graphene, boron nitride and transition metal dichalcogenide) hosting nanopores for ultrafast DNA and protein sequencing, or to investigate time-dependent transport in protein complexes for photosynthetic energy transfer. Besides fundamental interest in the interplay between quantum coherence, transfer efficiency, fluctuating environment-induced dephasing, and feedback of nonequilibrium electrons on the motion of atoms, the high performance computing simulations conducted on this project can significantly shorten the path toward functional devices for applications in biosensing and artificial photosynthetic light harvesting.

por.por_cntn:
The nonequilibrium quantum many-body problem where fast electrons interact with slow degrees of freedom appears in numerous subfields of research in chemistry, physics and chemical physics. For example, in chemistry and chemical physics of photosynthetic light harvesting, fast electrons interact with slow classical nuclei whose positions additionally fluctuate due to surrounding environment. In condensed matter and nanophysics, fast electrons interact with slow classical magnetic moments within magnetic materials of spintronic devices. Due to large number of degrees of freedom, fully quantum man-body treatment of such systems is prohibitively expensive, so that development of multiscale quantum-classical algorithms is necessary. In such algorithms, fast electrons are modeled using quantum mechanics, while slow degrees of freedom are modeled using classical physics. The motion of slow degrees of freedom introduces time-dependent potential into the quantum description of electrons, while electrons in turn generate different types of forces in classical equations governing time evolution of nuclei or localized magnetic moments.

The key achievement of this project has been the development of efficient time-dependent nonequilibrium Green function algorithms and scientific computer codes which scale linearly in the number of time steps, in contrast to previous such algorithms where the scaling is cubic. These algorithms have been combined in multiscale fashion with molecular dynamics codes for classical nuclei or atomistic spin dynamics codes for localized magnetic moments. The meaning of such coupling was elucidated using analytical theory which has revealed how quantum effects introduce time-retarded frictional forces into the classical equations.  

Intellectual Merit: The project has supported publication of 6 refereed journal articles and 2 articles that are in preparation, as well as the development of open source time-dependent nonequilibrium Green function code and the corresponding tutorials.  Three of these articles have introduce novel quantum-classical approach for spintronics, and another two articles have applied the same approach to subfields of chemistry and chemical physics, thereby making the whole project highly transdisciplinary. An additional article has developed new technique to resum divergent perturbative series in quantum mechanics which can be applied to improve efficiency of quantum time evolution. The time-dependent nonequilibrium Green function code has also been applied in one article to understand interaction of light and inversion asymmetric quantum materials.  

Broader impacts:  The project has supported two graduate students working on their Ph.D. thesis. These students, as well as two postdocs, where trained in wide range of theoretical and computational techniques of relevance for multiscale modeling of systems in chemistry, chemical physics and spintronics. This has included Keldysh Green function technique of nonequilibrium quantum statistical mechanics, multiscale quantum-classical approaches, molecular dynamics, classical atomistic spin dynamics, as well as the development of complex scientific codes using different programming languages and interfaces between them. The time-dependent nonequilibrium Green function code and tutorials are offered to world-wide audience as an open source project through a dedicated Website, https://qttg.gitlab.io/td2d_documentation/index.html. The demonstration of how to model efficiently light interaction with biological molecules or inversion asymmetric quantum materials could lead to novel solar energy technologies.
